title: Player Behaviour and Riot.
body:
https://www.gdcvault.com/play/1017940/The-Science-Behind-Shaping-Player

So i wanted to show people this again with respect to the recent ban spikes.

Riot have clearly lost sight of what they believed is the case.

Stop treating your average player like a toxic player.

replies.body:
It really would be interesting to see what the change was.

Has new software been rolled out?

Are new people at the helm? Or fewer, making player behaviour overworked and more reliant on automation?

Have they been instructed to go hard on previously minor issues?

I really wonder why the sudden change.

I just personally know that this is against what riot set out to do, and it's just fucking disgusting.

The amount of people that even have only 1 game chat logs is just not right.

Toxicity isn't something that can be beaten by just giving everyone 14 day bans.

> The amount of people that even have only 1 game chat logs is just not right.

Its what I got when I was perma banned on my main acc
Yeah which is pathetic if you watch the video, where they actually say that the average player will be toxic at times.

Maybe it is part of a bigger strategy to get new users hooked.

it sort of makes sense - with an aging population you need to get fresh blood. Parents wont let 13 year olds play if there are rude words, and riot probably dont stand to make much money off the old guard who are turned off by the new system. So they clear the decks and give the impression of a wholesome game just in time for the rollout of BE which is aimed at pulling money out of millions of teenagers in very small and regular amounts for a chance to get some flair for their account or a new champ.

It really could be a clearing the decks exercise to encourage younger players, which in itself is an exercise to open up a new market of players to an exploitative microtransaction model.
Funny thing is, what 13 year old would even know that much about league?
